channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: European Union Adds 15 Names to Ukraine Sanctions List
item.description: The announcement from Brussels came after Washington included key Kremlin aides on its expanded list of targets for sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL, ANDREW ROTH and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The European Union imposed asset freezes and travel bans on 15 Russians and Ukrainians, including Dmitri N. Kozak, a Russian deputy prime minister, seen here in March with President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Turkey to Seek Islamic Cleric's Return
item.description: Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will ask the United States to extradite an Islamic spiritual leader he has accused of orchestrating an alleged plot aimed to undermine and bring down his government.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Lobs Shells Near Disputed Sea Border
item.description: Thousands of South Korean islanders fled in panic to shelters after the North Korean military fired artillery rounds.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: British Economic Growth Accelerates in First Quarter
item.description: The 0.8 percent increase in gross domestic product, though lower than some analysts had predicted, outstripped the 0.7 percent of the previous three months.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Europe’s Antitrust Chief Censures Google’s Motorola Mobility
item.description: The case involved a patent dispute with Apple in Germany, in which the European Commission said Motorola used a court order to stifle competition.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Poll Shows Increasing Dissatisfaction With Beijing
item.description: Most notably, young people in Hong Kong are dissatisfied with the way the central government in Beijing is overseeing its relations with the former British colony, the survey finds.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pedestrians crossing a busy street in Hong Kong, where more than half of those polled said they were not satisfied with Beijing's management of the territory.

item.title: India Ink: John Oliver on the American Media’s India Blind Spot
item.description: The host of the satirical “Last Week Tonight” took Americans and American news outlets to task for ignoring the largest democratic exercise in the world, but he did not spare the Indian news media.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Bombs Kill at Least 17 People at Iraq Market
item.description: A pair of back-to-back bombs ripped through an outdoor market northeast of Baghdad on Tuesday, killing at least 17 people and wounding 42, officials said, the latest spasm of violence to convulse Iraq ahead of parliamentary elections.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: EU Names 15 New Targets for Sanctions
item.description: The European Union on Tuesday released the names of 15 new targets of sanctions because of their roles in the Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: No Compensation for Parents Who Have Lost Their Only Child
item.description: The family planning authorities have declined to compensate families who lose their only child, arguing there is no legal basis for such compensation, in a move stirring disappointment and criticism among the families.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman holding a baby on a street in central Beijing.

item.title: South Korea’s President Apologizes for Ferry Disaster
item.description: Under mounting public pressure, President Park Geun-hye apologized for a ferry disaster that left 302 people dead or missing and promised broad reforms.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea paid her respects at a memorial for victims of the Sewol ferry disaster on Tuesday in Ansan.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Demolition Begins on Church That Triggered Protest
item.description: Thousands of worshipers in the southeastern Chinese province of Zhejiang had tried to protect the church after the authorities said it violated local building codes.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Lens Blog: Twenty Years After Apartheid
item.description: Joao Silva came of age as a photographer as his native South Africa was navigating a treacherous path to democracy. Twenty years later, he reflects on what has — and has not — changed.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JOAO SILVA
item.media:description: Ken Oosterbroek being carried by a fellow photographer, Gary Bernard, after Mr. Oosterbroek was fatally wounded while covering fighting in Tokoza. Greg Marinovich was injured in the fighting. April 18, 1994.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Xinjiang, Xi Pushes Vision of Uighur Integration
item.description: On his visit to the restless province of Xinjiang, President Xi Jinping of China has cast himself as a paternal leader devoted to improving the lives of ordinary people, but also as a firm proponent of a security state dedicated to defending social stability and one-party power.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Chinese Journalist Missing Ahead of Tiananmen Commemoration
item.description: Friends say that Gao Yu may have been detained by the authorities ahead of the 25th anniversary of the armed crackdown.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 29
item.description: A roundup of local election-related news for Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Supporters of the Bharatiya Janata Party at an election rally addressed by the party's prime ministerial candidate Narendra Modi in Gujarat on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: 2nd Publisher Pressured Over Hindu Book by U.S. Scholar
item.description: Since Aleph Book Company decided to hold off on reprinting a book by Wendy Doniger after being threatened with a lawsuit, a co-founder has left and at least two authors are considering leaving as well.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR

item.title: India Ink: India and Pakistan Under Prime Minister Singh
item.description: Though the departing prime minister cannot point to any groundbreaking achievements, political analysts say his policy on Pakistan was pragmatic and saw moderate success despite some serious setbacks.
item.dc:creator: By KABIR TANEJA
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh worked for most of his 10-year tenure to build bridges with Pakistan.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Mayor Detained in Organized Crime Investigation
item.description: The arrest of the mayor, Arquímedes Oseguera, on Monday came a day after five people were killed on the outskirts of Lázaro Cárdenas when vigilante groups clashed with gunmen who they suspected were criminals.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Hospital Raid
item.description: Doctors Without Borders expressed outrage on Monday over the weekend killings of 16 civilians, including three staff members, on the property of a hospital it runs in the Central African Republic.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Ethiopia: 9 Media Workers Arrested
item.description: Nine bloggers and journalists were arrested in Addis Ababa last week just days before Secretary of State John Kerry’s scheduled visit to Ethiopia on Tuesday.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Arc of a Failed Deal: How Nine Months of Mideast Talks Ended in Disarray
item.description: As a nine-month deadline for an Israeli-Palestinian peace deal passes, new punitive measures in progress and other moves could bring an intractable conflict to a new low.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry with President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority in Amman, Jordan, in March, one of their 34 meetings over nine months of negotiations.

item.title: Kerry Expresses Regret After Apartheid Remark
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed support for Israel after a controversy erupted over a phrase he used in a private appearance.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Ending Asia Trip, Obama Defends His Foreign Policy
item.description: President Obama said his policies were based on a workmanlike attention to American priorities that might lack the high drama of a wartime presidency but also avoids ruinous mistakes.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and President Benigno S. Aquino III during a state dinner Monday night at Malacanang Palace in Manila.

item.title: U.S. Couple Denied Permission to Leave Qatar While Appeal is Pending
item.description: The couple, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles, were convicted last month of child endangerment in the death of their adopted daughter from Africa.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SHABINA S. KHATRI
